You can see that "Processing on-demand claims." is logged once after authentication and once after driver connection is established. We've done changes around device claims many times over the years to fix various issues and this could be intentional. So investigate that first please.

This isn't really an Envy problem, but more to do with confd and Azure WireServer. It's also regional, provisioning works on
. Confd fetches the ssh key from WireServer, but for some reason fails to do that in west europe.
A workaround in Envy would be to change region to
. However currently our azure resource manager has a limit of 10 vcpu in east us. West europe has a limit of 80 vcpu. We need to increase the limits on east us if we are to do the workaround.

When updating Electron the dist bundle needs to be manually uploaded to nexus. Let's figure out what we can do.

An option is to create a generic http proxy repository for electron on nexus (I've done this for a few things, such as gradle and FIDO2 metadata). But if there is a more standard way of doing it, that could be better.
chromedriver/electron zips are on nexus. Here is a script which can update them if you are using a proper OS:

#!/bin/bash

ver=$1
user=$2
pass=$3

files=(SHASUMS256.txt)

for os in darwin linux win32; do
    for arch in arm64 x64; do
        for exe in chromedriver electron; do
	          files+=("$exe-$ver-$os-$arch.zip")
	      done
    done
done

for file in ${files[@]}; do
    echo "Downloading $file ..."
    wget -q -O $file
I used that to upload v36.4.0 to nexus since Pettor created a PR for that.
That (or similar) script exists in the repo actually.
We weren't sure if it was actually using nexus since the Vite migration, now we are given
But we want to make changes so that this manual step is not needed and renovate can make PRs. An idea is to create a separate proxy for electron on nexus.
Yeah that would nice to avoid the extra steps.

Yes it's in the kernel change linked below. We can fix it by not setting
sockets. I can fix that in vpnd
REUSEPORT was restricted to INET sockets (IPv4/IPv6 TCP/UDP/SCTP/ICMP/RAW) to fix a bug in another protocol implementation that does not support SO
REUSEPORT can be set to any socket family but had effect only on the INET socket families above. So, it should not be set on AF
server.c#L3383 so it is in 6.5.1 The one who put fix version did a mistake. Will change it to 6.5.1

No customer impact. Is just we noticed something stopped working in new ubuntu snapshot which 6.5.1 would get and made it work again. That's why no release notes were added in 6.5.1.

You can keep it as a cron job, but I think that its probably a bit nicer to use a systemd timer... I went ahead and drafted a service and timer unit file that I've been using in testing:

[Unit]
Description=GeoIP Database Updater
Wants=network-online.target
After=network-online.target

[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=cz-geoip --config /etc/cz-geoip/config.json
WorkingDirectory=/tmp
ProtectSystem=strict
ProtectHome=true
ReadWritePaths=/mnt/data/geoip /var/run/cz-agentx/stats/cz-geoip.json
PrivateTmp=true
NoNewPrivileges=true

[Unit]
Description=Run GeoIP Database Updater daily

[Timer]
OnCalendar=daily
RandomizedDelaySec=30m
Persistent=true

[Install]
WantedBy=timers.target

Regarding the "AfterUpdateCommands", maybe that could be taken care of by configd instead. Configd keeps track of the different services and their associated files. We could let configd reload those services if the db file has changed. Then cz-geoip would not need to run as root.

tell you whenever it changed the DB...

I looked closer into the file watching from configd, and I think it is still best if cz-geoip invokes the reload. Configd will reload the right services if the watched files have changed but only if there are some events happening (such as an appliance config change). So it might take an unknown amount of time after the cron / systemd timer job for them to be reloaded.
I'm fine leaving it running as root, but one thing that we could try is something like this in the sudoers file:

%czd ALL=(czd-priv) NOPASSWD:/usr/sbin/cz-reload cz-logd
%czd ALL=(czd-priv) NOPASSWD:/usr/sbin/cz-reload cz-sessiond
%czd ALL=NOPASSWD:/usr/sbin/systemctl reload cz-controllerd

"AfterUpdateCommands": [
        ["sudo", "-u", "czd-priv", "cz-reload", "cz-logd"], 
        ["sudo", "-u", "czd-priv", "cz-reload","cz-sessiond"], // If we have the GW role
        ["sudo", "systemctl", "reload", "cz-controllerd"] // If we have the CTR role
    ],

. In that way we leave configd to reload the services if and only the db file has changed and cz-geoip can run as czd user/group. Only the notify service would need to run as root.

On register/unregister/listServices → update signature and clear local cache.
, compare their local signature with the stored one.

| State | DB Registration (token+URL) | ztpServices | Meaning | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | S0 | Absent | Empty | Unregistered, no cache | | S1 | Present | Empty | Just registered, not fetched yet | | S2 | Present | Populated (current) | Healthy cache | | S3 | Absent | Populated (stale) | Should be invalidated but isn’t yet | | S4 | Present (new) | Populated (old) | Re-registered but stale cache reused | | S5 | Present (new) | Populated (fresh) | Healthy after reload |

iirc Arturo (maybe Dan too) looked at this in detail and concluded it was latency - controllers and ZTP are geographically far apart.
There is a potential improvement to parallelize API calls but not yet sure that's worth it.
We've decided to parallelize the calls but realized it's a bit of a risky change to do now due to various signature changes. So let's do it on the next release.

This is the story to try and collect all our STIG related tasks and questions. I expect this ticket to be a bit messy in the beginning, but hopefully it can clear up over time. I will use the story for random note taking too. Feel free to edit and add.
See attached HTML file for complete output
V-260470 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS, when booted, must require authentication upon booting into single-user and maintenance modes. - Fail
Same as V-238204 but with a another broken check. Grub should get locked after reboot post-install of the customization. Check is broken because we have an unusual partitioning scheme

V-260650 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must implement NIST FIPS-validated cryptography to protect classified information and for the following: To provision digital signatures, to generate cryptographic hashes, and to protect unclassified information requiring confidentiality and cryptographic protection in accordance with applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, and standards. - Fail
We don't have a subscription for Ubuntu Pro plan to be able to enable FIPS. Subscription is required to obtain the FIPS Kernel cryptographic module
V-260471 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must initiate session audits at system startup. - Fail
V-260488 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must configure the "/var/log" directory to have mode "755" or less permissive. - Fail
Syslog daemon won't be able to write logs
V-260490 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must generate system journal entries without revealing information that could be exploited by adversaries. - Fail
V-260500 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS library files must be group-owned by "root". - Fail
V-260512 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must be configured so that the "journalctl" command is not accessible by unauthorized users. - Fail
Disabling journalctl doesn't protect anything. Users won't be able to read log files if we disable them.

V-260531 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must configure the SSH daemon to use FIPS 140-3-approved ciphers to prevent the unauthorized disclosure of information and/or detect changes to information during transmission. - Fail
False positive. We have the same
V-260534 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must use strong authenticators in establishing nonlocal maintenance and diagnostic sessions. - Fail

Without proper knowledge and experimentation of PAM, we don't recommend enabling PAM as it opens a whole can of worms (PAM is usually the top findings for vulnerability reports). Blindly enabling this feature, may make the system less secure. Given the current timeframe, we will skip this.
V-260542 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must prevent direct login into the root account. - Fail
Faulty regular expression - root account has no hash for the possible
V-260546 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must enforce a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction. Passwords for new users must have a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction. - Fail

Users could be potentially locked out of the system completely if they forget to update their password. Once they are locked out, there is no way of getting back in without formatting the entire appliance and starting fresh.
V-260547 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must disable account identifiers (individuals, groups, roles, and devices) after 35 days of inactivity. - Fail
SDP is running on a server, nobody should be logging in and out. Could be done but they must remember to peroiodcally login and change it or they will be locked out forever.
V-260553 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must allow users to directly initiate a session lock for all connection types. - Fail
V-260569 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must store only encrypted representations of passwords. - Fail
V-260589 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must monitor remote access methods. - Fail
V-260472 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must restrict access to the kernel message buffer. - Fail
Kernel message buffer is already disabled by default. Just not set via the file which is commented out.
V-260479 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must have the "chrony" package installed. - Fail

Switching from ntp -> chrony requires a significant change to configd - not possible without a new release. We install, configure and run the ntp services, as well as our ntp health checks and ntpq appliance command. We have an old ticket
V-260481 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must not have the "ntp" package installed. - Fail

Switching from ntp -> chrony requires a significant change to configd - not possible without a new release. We install, configure and run the ntp services, as well as our ntp health checks and ntpq appliance command. We have an old ticket
V-260549 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must automatically lock an account until the locked account is released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts have been made. - Fail
We don't enable PAM - See V-260534
V-260581 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must be configured such that Pluggable Authentication Module (PAM) prohibits the use of cached authentications after one day. - Fail
We don't enable PAM - See V-260534

V-260596 - Ubuntu 22.04 LTS must immediately notify the system administrator (SA) and information system security officer (ISSO) when the audit record storage volume reaches 25 percent remaining of the allocated capacity. - Fail
About V-260479 and V-260481, we have a ticket to replace ntpd with chrony as the appliance's ntp daemon
This is not a small task as we would need to change the we install, configure and run the ntp services, as well as our ntp health checks and ntpq appliance command.
I was just playing with profile push on my client. I have a bunch of profiles lying about.
Say I have a profile called OKTA from my env.
If I push profiles OKTA and local, and then restart the client, I stay on OKTA.
If I push a profile group with OKTA in it, then I stay on OKTA. If OKTA is with 0 weight, I go to the other profile in the group (I think. Should test this.).
If I push only local profile, so OKTA gets removed, then I end up on purple profile.
("No current session logic, selecting the highest prioritized profile.");
I expected it to select local since that replaced my profile.
I think it only happens if I restart the client. Had trouble reproducing it with signout.
There are no visible problems but there are errors in the console.
